caption: A simple and fun idea which made this wall a landmark. I enjoyed visiting here and seeing other visitors and the local market around it. However, don't have very high expectations beyond what you are in the images.

Had family visiting and we stopped here for a quick look. It's a super cute and quite romantic initiative and the tourists absolutely loved it. It was cute to see people trying to find their 'I love you' in there language. We sat on the benches for a while and there was an amazing busker outside singing - he was so awesome.

A lovely little initiative showcasing ‚ÄúI love you‚Äù in every language around the world. Located in Montmartre, very close walking distance to the Sacre Coeur and a variety of cafes and restaurants. Found in a small park, which often has buskers out the front playing lovely acoustic music.  Busy with lovers, so get there early to get a photo.

Beautiful spot covered in the word "love" in various languages. Unfortunately, when I visited, it was closed, so I had to take photos from the outside. Even though I couldn‚Äôt see it up close, the view from the outside still captured the essence of the place. If you‚Äôre a fan of art and romance, it‚Äôs worth a visit on your next trip.
The "I love you wall is located in a small park. The area is busy lots of people. It free. Again, there are lots of people, but they leave as fast as they come .

What a magical and romantic place, saying I LOVE YOU in around 300 different languages, a divided heart that when put together becomes a whole symbol of love and cherish.

This is such a cute place! I would recommend coming early in the morning (as you see it was very crowded around lunch time). It is convenient to combine it with the visit to Montmartre as it is just down the hill üòä There are maaany languages, even expressions in different dialects of the same language (there is Dutch but also Flemish)!

A nice romantic place in the city of love Paris. The wall mural has 'I LOVE YOU' written in 300+ languages. I was easily able to find 2 languages of my country: Hindi and Gujarati. The park is also a very nice place to chill and relax. It is small but very calm and peaceful. Entry is free and you can visit this place as it is very close to Sacre Coeur which is a major tourist attraction in Montmarte area of Paris. To click pictures as couples visit early in the morning as it is not crowded. This place has very romantic vibes. Wall of love in city of love.
very cute! sit for a while to spend some time trying to discover new ways to say "te amo" üíú
Nice wall, it‚Äôs what it‚Äôs reported to be, just a wall with ‚ÄúI love you‚Äù written in hundreds of languages. Beautifully new renovated park, the Square Jehan-Rictus.
The area around this park is quite nice and chic. The park is small and a bit crowded always.

Remember Emily in Paris S3 E9 title "Love is in the Air"?  This is the I Love You wall!  Located in Montmartre, it was not far from a beautiful poster display of Philippine Leroy-Beaulieu (Sylvie Grateux), steps away from the Wallace Fountain.
This wall of love is a small exhibit open to public for free, you can fimd your language take pictures.  Love it...üòç‚ù§Ô∏è

The "Wall of Love" is a dreamy spot for romantic photos with your partner, featuring "I love you" in many languages. Adding a love lock on the railings is a sweet touch. Just be ready for the crowd and a bit of a wait due to everyone trying to capture the love-filled atmosphere! ‚ù§Ô∏èüì∏üòç

Well worth stopping by if you are in Montmartre. ‚ÄúI love you‚Äù in multiple languages and people were having fun finding their own language
This is a very cute wall. But super touristy and crowded. You could barely get a good picture with no one around you.
During our leisurely walk down the hill, we dropped into a love garden area, that is home to the love wall, with the words "I Love You" in many different languages.
A lovely little garden with a Wall of Love where I love you is written in 300 languages. Can get busy during the day. Recommend going there in the morning.
I went for the experience, but it's not the same as the locks are no longer allowed on the bridge. People have resorted to placing the locks on signs around the bridge.

Paris known as the City of Love, the "Wall of Love" in Montmartre embodies this sentiment beautifully. Nestled in a quaint park, this mosaic masterpiece displays "I Love You" in over 300 languages, celebrating love's universality. Touching the cool tiles and tracing the words with my fingers made the experience profoundly personal. A heartfelt stop for couples or anyone cherishing the power of love. A really cool place to stop if you‚Äôre in montmarte. It‚Äôs super close to the metro station so it‚Äôs easy to visit before you head up to the top of hill. This is a place where every country citizens feel proud because they can see i love you written in their own language, as we seen in Hindi language.
Cute wall with I love you written in 300 languages ü•∞ in mid-October, on a Thursday, not too many people.

Wall of love - as per my knowledge it is a wall which has 'i love you' in all the languages in the world. And it is a small park as well for sitting. üëâ I found my mother tounge there.. i am so happy and the wall was really nice spot.

The Wall of Love is an interesting place in Montmartre. A lot of people gather, waiting in line to take a photo with their loved one, or compare some love verse. A bit of a problem is the lush vegetation that covers a large part of this area.
A beautiful Wall of I love you's in a lot of languages. A lot of tourists but it's in an active area.

This is the famous ‚ÄúMontmartre of Love‚Äù (Le Mur des Je t‚Äôaime), also known as ‚ÄúThe Wall of Love‚Äù, located in Paris, in the Montmartre area. It is an artistic installation that features the phrase ‚ÄúI love you‚Äù written in over 300 languages and dialects.  The artwork was created by Fr√©d√©ric Baron and Claire Kito and is a popular spot for romantic walks and photographs.

What a cute and fun place. Great for photo ops. Love that it has so many languages on it and some of them in multiple languages. Here  are a few of my photos. It can be crowded but if you wait a few minutes the crowd usually fizzled out and you‚Äôll be able to get a better picture. I was also there in February when it was quite cold so not as large of a crowd as there might be there in warmer months. You don‚Äôt need a ticket to get here so don‚Äôt let anyone scam you into buying a ticket

I came here because of Emily in Paris üòú. It's basically a small park with a huge mural wall that displays I Love You in many languages. I probably don't really have to explain this because it's so obvious but I don't know what else to say about this place. Oh perhaps a good information will be, by 8.30pm you need to leave the place as the guard will make everyone do so immediately and close the gate.

Nothing too spectacular, it's in a small gated garden with green plants but no flowers. Also as you can see it can get crowded. We found the best angle standing on a bench
